app_description:
eMin uses a technology-driven approach to better enable governance over recruitment and employment practices in global value chains through contracts, worker surveys and e-learning.

The platform aims to:
1.	Eliminate employment fraud and forced labour
2.	Incentivise agents and corporations to act ethically and responsibly
3.	Improve visibility of supply chains for managers, auditors and regulators

Worker Features 
 👨‍👩‍👦 Transparent and immutable conditions of work through secure document storage and multi-party sharing and verification of contracts

📣 Amplified voice through surveys providing insights on working conditions directly 

📺 E-learnings from IOM & Diginex Solutions (Modern Slavery Prevention & Covid-19)

Supplier Features 
📑 Ability to upload and share work contracts and other key documents securely and to share with workers and brand 

💻 E-learnings from IOM & Diginex Solutions

Brand Features

👨🏽‍💻 Ability to connect directly with workers via customized surveys to verify compliance . Survey responses can be anonymized.

📜 View shared worker contracts (subject to worker permissioning) or standard contract template

📊 Simple dashboard showing results of worker surveys
app_subtitle: Designed to protect migrant workers and increase supply chain transparency

qatar_description:
There are around two million migrant workers in Qatar.
Service providers and placement agencies (and the recruitment agencies they may utilise, should not charge workers any recruitment fees and related costs (Qatar Labour Law and Ministerial Decision No. 8 of 2005)
kuwait_description: There are around three million migrant workers in Kuwait. The Labour Law of Kuwait does not explictly state who is responsible for covering recruitment fees and related costs.
bahrain_description: There are around 600,900 migrant workers in Bahrain. The Labour Law of Bahrain does not explictly state who is responsible for covering recruitment fees and related costs.
oman_description: There are around 1.8 million migrant workers in Oman. The Labour Law of Oman does not explictly state who is responsible for covering recruitment fees and related costs.
saudi_arabia_description: There are around 13 million migrant workers in Saudi Arabia. The charging of recruitment fees and related costs to foreign migrant workers employed by the private sector is not permitted. The Labour Law of Saudia Arabia does not explicitly ban the charging of recruitment fees for domestic workers but it is illegal for employers to deduct fees from workers' salaries.
uae_description: There are around 7.8 million migrant workers in UAE.  The charging of recruitment fees and related costs to foreign migrant workers employed by the private sector is not permitted (UAE Labour Law, No. 8, 1980)
enter_total_cost: Enter total cost or let the system calculate

other_destination_description: “Those who go abroad cannot be winners in every way. There are always losses somewhere. All one can see is money. One can impress with land and beautiful buildings but what are the inner feelings, only the migrant knows. When I consider myself, I think I both lost and gained.” - Shahana (26 years old)
